awd_titl_txt: S&AS:FND:COLLAB:Unsupervised Rare Event Learning - With Applications on Autonomous Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
Intelligent physical systems (IPSs) architecture must be cognizant, taskable, adaptive, and ethical, particularly when users need to reliably address uncertain, dynamically changing situations. Despite the collection and availability of massive data on IPSs, a significant challenge, faced by the autonomous vehicle (AV) industry is the capability to efficiently anticipate and avoid rare but catastrophic failure events. Developing an information structure that enables users to make the best use of massive data and to model the complexity and rarity of critical situations would contribute to addressing this challenge. This project investigates a novel, unsupervised rare-event learning framework for AV research that utilizes the collected data to assess and alleviate the risks, limitations, and failure modes of IPSs. The framework combines the flexibility in modeling high-dimensional time-series driving data via unsupervised learning algorithms, with the statistical robustness and computational efficiency from rare-event analysis. 

The specific goals of the research include: 1) formulate an effective framework to extract safety-critical information from driving database; 2) develop a solid probabilistic measurement scheme for rare but adverse events in AV driving contexts; 3) disseminate the framework and research outcomes to industry and government units in urgent need of reliable evaluation and development methods; and 4) cross-fertilize research thrusts between the academic communities of rare-event estimation and the study of IPSs. The research will merge high-fidelity driving representations learned from data and statistically rigorous rare event analysis so that AV design evaluation in simulated complex driving situations will become highly efficient. It will synthesize machine learning with simulation methodologies, including rare-event analysis, stochastic optimization, and particle methods to boost the performances of state-of-the-art algorithms. The project will foster transformative academic cross-fertilization between researchers in rare-event estimation (operations research) and IPSs (machine learning/robotics), by disseminating the outcomes in top-tier journals, conferences, tutorials and invited seminars. The research will train under-represented minority students at the PIs' institutions, provide opportunities to meet key AV academic and industry players, and show them how to apply mathematical and engineering skills to improve transportation mobility, safety, and roadway efficiency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied reliable simulation-based and data-centric methods for the safety evaluation of black-box systems that are important in applications such as autonomous vehicles. A major focus is the likelihood evaluation of rare but catastrophic events as a safety indicator. To this end, event rarity imposes the statistical challenge of unobservability in standard experiments, and necessitates the use of so-called variance reduction techniques that aim to increase the frequency of target rare event hits while maintaining statistical correctness. This project investigated more versatile, nonetheless theoretically grounded, methodologies to handle the sophistication faced by complex black-box models that are beyond the reach of conventional, typically model-specific and rigid, variance reduction techniques. The investigation involved the reduction of required information or conditions, invention of new guarantees that are more suitable for black-box models, and new connections with machine learning and modern mathematical programming.

 Technically, the project created a learning-based approach for rare-event safety evaluation by integrating classification tools to learn black-box-model-induced rare-events in the first stage, and applying statistically guaranteed importance sampling in the second stage. The learning stage utilizes neural networks that are trained and validated in relation to the rare-event geometry and exhibit computational advantages in designing the downstream importance samplers. The project also created new efficiency notions to relax standard criteria driven by relative errors to one-sided guarantees, and to criteria that bypass the over-conservative use of variance as an error measure. The project also developed techniques that leverage sequential mixed integer programming to search for dominating points of machine-learning-represented rare-event sets, in order to guide the construction of efficient importance samplers. Finally, the project developed approaches to learn importance samplers in dynamic settings, and derived results to understand the impacts of tail misinformation, distribution shifts, and subsequently distributionally robustify safety evaluations.

The project has been used to train multiple PhD students including under-represented minorities, and to create undergraduate research opportunities. The results have been incorporated in courses in simulation and trustworthy AI. The research has cross-fertilized multiple disciplines including operations research (such as simulation and optimization) and machine learning (such as deep learning and reinforcement learning). The outcomes have been disseminated in top-tier journals and conferences in operations research, machine learning, robotics and transportation. The results have been presented in major conferences and specialized workshops in machine learning, AI, statistics, and operations research. Lastly, implementation codes and manuscripts related to the project research are made publicly available.
